_header: Man may long lives ween / Ac oft him lie the wrench
_description: Admonition to prepare for Death — five 10-line stanzas

BodLauMis471.First Lines:
Man may longe liwes wenenac offte hym legeþt se
                    wrench…
BodLauMis471.Last Lines:
…awinnet him a þusend þine oþer mo ne do
                    þu so
BodLauMis471.Note:
Lines 1-2 occur also at f. 133 in the prose Sermo Dominica in
                        Sexagesima; written as prose.

         Halle: Neimeyer, 1912. 
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.

         Oxford: Clarendon, 1932: 15-18.

             “Zu R. Morris, An Old English Miscellany, pp. 156-159.” 
             Anglia
         1 (1878): 410-14: 411-12.
Stevick,  Robert D.,
                        ed.  
             One Hundred Middle English Lyrics.
         Indianapolis: Bobbs-Merrill, 1964: 6-8 (critical text).

OxfJesus29.First Lines:
Mon may longe lyues weneAc ofte him lyeþ þe
                    wrench…
OxfJesus29.Last Lines:
…Wurcheþ him þyne euer moMon ne do þu nouht
                    swo

Morris,  Richard,

BLAru57.Transcription: Man may longe his lyues weneand ofte him lyeȝeþ his wrenchAse nayrweder went in to repeand nerliche makeþ his blenchþer ne is noþer king ne kneueþet ne ssel drinke of deaþes drenchman þeruore þe be þencher þou nalle of þi benchþi zenne aquench
BLAru57.Note: First stanza only. Written as prose.

BLCottCalAIX.First Lines: Non mai longe liues ƿeneac ofte him liueð þe wrench…
BLCottCalAIX.Last Lines: …Wurcheþ him pine euer moMon ne do þu noþt sƿo
